title: Enterprise assets
content:
Enterprise Asset Management is available for Service Management Premium and Asset Management licenses only.

Enterprise assets mainly refer to the non-IT assets owned or used within your organization to support its operation and seamless function. Through the application of Enterprise Asset Management (EAM), we provide a centralized platform to oversee the end-to-end lifecycle of your enterprise assets. This will optimize resource allocation, minimize downtimes, and extend asset lifespans.

For each enterprise asset, you can define its Subtype and Process type based on specific categories and their lifecycles. Out of the box, there're three process types of enterprise assets, and each has its corresponding workflow:

  • Full-ownership assets mean the organization or individual has complete ownership and responsibility for the entire lifecycle of the asset. See Full-ownership assets workflow.
  • Consumable assets need to be disposed of considering the legal, environmental, or regulatory requirements when they are used up or expired.​ For example, office supplies, fuel, and chemicals. Some consumable assets may have expiration dates, so there is a transition from being in stock to disposal. See Consumable assets workflow.
  • Stationary assets typically refer to fixed assets that remain in a fixed location and aren't easily moved. For example, buildings, land, conference rooms, and elevators.​ See Stationary assets workflow.

You can also create an Asset Model for the Enterprise asset, and associate an enterprise asset subtype with the model. Then, when creating an enterprise asset, you can specify an enterprise asset model in the Model field. See Asset models for guidance.

If you are using Enterprise Assets for the first time, there will be more Service Portal users generating requests related to Enterprise Assets. Ensure that you reevaluate the deployment size based on the potential number of concurrent users. Refer to the deployment sizing documents according to the platform you're using and increase the hardware resources (for example, CPU and memory) accordingly.
